text.text: What is Equitable Resilience?
Building community resilience to climate change and hazards must center equity throughout the planning process.
Figure 1. Key ERB concepts and their relevance to equitable resilience.

Equitable resilience considers social vulnerability and varying access to power, knowledge, and resources. It requires starting from peopleâ€™s own perception of their position with their social and environmental relationships [1]. The impacts of climate change and hazards are not experienced evenly within and across communities. Certain population groups such as the elderly, youth, persons with disabilities, low-income householders, Black, Latinx, Asian American, Indigenous, and other persons of color, and immigrants tend to experience greater financial, health, and social impacts from disasters.

Equitable resilience describes the capacity to withstand, respond, adapt, and transform in the face of climate change and disasters in ways that are culturally appropriate, participatory, and enhances the resilience of the community, not just individual resilience. Equitable resilience acknowledges deeply rooted social forces that affect how community members are made vulnerable to disaster and climate risk, may experience cascading consequences of incidents, and bear disproportionate benefits burdens of actions to increase resilience [2].
Equitable Resilience Builder (ERB) process (Figure 2) is designed to support local practitioners integrate equitable and resilience
into various types of planning activities.
Figure 2. The ERB process centers integrates equity and engagement throughout the planning process.
How do communities benefit from using the ERB tool?

A resilient community is one in which all members of a community can effectively prepare for and recover from hazard impacts. The ERB tool and activities centers equity throughout the planning process
A stronger network of community organizations and agencies to share information and resources
Facilitation guides for holding workshops in trauma-informed ways
Activity guides for soliciting community perspectives
Local knowledge is valued and utilized alongside scientific data
Data and maps on hazards, equity, and resilient community systems
Locally meaningful and measurable indicators to measure future change in built, natural, and social environment systems
A collaboratively prioritized set of actions and next steps for strengthening community resilience in an equitable way
